metadata.title: Protocol: A distal lung organoid model to study interstitial lung disease, viral infection and human lung development

annotations.description: Directed differentiation of human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) into distal lung organoids through sequential specification: definitive endoderm → anterior foregut endoderm → ventral anterior foregut endoderm → lung bud organoids → lung organoids.
Organoid generation takes ~40 days and can be maintained for >180 days, maturing to a stage consistent with the second trimester of human gestation.
Organoids exhibit branching morphology, near absence of non-lung endodermal lineages, presence of mesenchyme, and capacity to recapitulate interstitial lung diseases.
Protocol is performed in serum-free conditions without lineage-specific reporters or enrichment steps; requires familiarity with cell culture techniques.
Protocol includes generation of single-cell suspensions for single-cell RNA sequencing.
Early stages: embryoid body formation (d0–d6) using Y-27632, Activin A, BMP4, SB 431542, CHIR 99021, IWP2, bFGF, Noggin.
Anterior foregut endoderm induction (d6–d25) using BMP4, CHIR 99021, SB 431542, retinoic acid, KGF (FGF7), FGF10.
Lung bud organoid (LBO) generation in suspension culture (d8–d15) with FGF10 and KGF (FGF7).
Embedding of LBOs in Matrigel to induce branching morphogenesis (d25–d150).
Organoids at d170 correspond to second-trimester human fetal lung by transcriptomic benchmarking against Keygenes database.
AT2 cells emerge at tips by late culture stages; contain lamellar bodies (LBs) and can uptake/secrete fluorescently labeled SFTPB.
Mesenchyme appears during anteriorization/ventralization and becomes scarce after Matrigel embedding.
Organoids model fibrotic interstitial lung diseases (ILDs), including Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome (HPS1, HPS2, HPS4 mutations), but not HPS8.
Interleukin-11 identified as a therapeutic target for fibrosis via comparative transcriptomics of HPS mutant organoids.
Organoids can be infected by respiratory viruses (RSV, parainfluenza, measles) and recapitulate in vivo infection phenotypes (e.g., epithelial dislodgement).
Single-cell RNA sequencing and confocal analysis used to track loss of non-lung endodermal fates and acquisition of distal lung fate during development.
